stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream blocking-out "Astral Arcade" (Course 15) and brainstorming how pinball-style actors will work in 3-D.  He alternates between Blender modeling, shader/texture tests, and high-level layout talk.

development_findings.summary: Astral Arcade now has a clear high-level plan: a main ‘table’ area on top, with flipper parts floating underneath; players collect coins and use flipper elements to shoot back up.
development_findings.quote: Below the main area are all the flipper pieces; you can collect coins down there and then just shoot up whenever you want and land back in the main area.

development_findings.summary: Design goal is ‘Mario Galaxy philosophy’—looks open but is secretly linear, achieved by narrow, branching paths that intersect via warps.
development_findings.quote: It should feel open but be linear, kind of like Mario Galaxy.

development_findings.summary: Key pinball actors being prototyped: rotating flipper paddle, spherical bumper that reflects the launch vector, triangular bumper that deflects toward its point, trampoline button that launches the player upward, and purely static metal platforms.

Visual language trials: experimenting with glow, emissive materials, spring decals, and transparent shells to communicate ‘bounce’.  Struggles with making a full sphere look like a bumper; may switch to half-spheres or add billboarded rings/springs.
development_findings.quote: The non-hemisphere is just impossible… maybe we take the L and use a half-sphere.

development_findings.summary: Workflow: gray-box pieces first, then pass to Biobak for texture polish.
development_findings.quote: I'm sure Biobak will improve this anyway; for now it's fine as a placeholder.

development_findings.summary: Technical side project: discovered an extra unused 1 MB of N64 RAM and cache tricks for future videos/hacks.
development_findings.quote: There's like an entire megabyte of N64 memory we can use—which is crazy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze recently bought a new microphone; production values for videos should improve, but he needs a sturdier stand.
context_findings.quote: It sounds much better when I'm up close… maybe I need a new microphone stand.

context_findings.summary: He is unusually irritated by YouTube comments lately and is seeking ways to ignore negativity.
context_findings.quote: I don't know what it is, but recently I've been getting so much more annoyed at my YouTube comments.

context_findings.summary: Spends off-stream hours on a long-delayed commissioned ROM-hack set in real-world cities, limiting time on Yoshi’s Island.
context_findings.quote: That hack is going to keep me very busy over the next few days, unfortunately, so I can only get little work done on RTYI.

context_findings.summary: Discusses odd sponsorship offers, including sunflower-seed samples and a company asking for photos to 3-D print a sex toy—illustrates comedic, sometimes uncomfortable side of creator economics.
context_findings.quote: They want pictures to make your own sex toy—this email is literally asking me for cock pics.

biobak.summary: Expected to re-texture and polish the placeholder flipper and bumper models once Kaze finalizes shapes.

key_stories.title: The Bumper Sphere Problem
key_stories.summary: Kaze spends over an hour trying to design a 3-D bumper that intuitively signals ‘bounce’. Full spheres look wrong; textures JPEG-artifact; chat suggestions spiral.  He considers half-spheres and billboard tricks but ends the stream unresolved.
key_stories.challenge: Create a spherical bumper that conveys pinball physics in 3-D.
key_stories.process: Tried beach-ball textures, emissive rings, metal cages, and transparent shells while debating ideas with chat.
key_stories.outcome: No satisfactory design yet; may pivot to half-spheres next session.
key_stories.key_quote: No, the non-hemisphere is just impossible to pull off—I might have to take the L.

key_stories.title: An Unusual Sponsorship Pitch
key_stories.summary: Kaze reads a cold-email from a company offering to 3-D print a replica dildo based on his anatomy, turning the moment into comedy and chat discussion about sponsorship absurdities.
key_stories.challenge: Decide whether to engage with an off-brand, invasive sponsor request.
key_stories.process: Publicly reads the email, jokes about verification logistics, and ultimately dismisses it.
key_stories.outcome: Serves as commentary on the bizarre offers indie creators receive.
key_stories.key_quote: This email is asking me for cock pics—what?
